title: Understanding Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease
content: Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is the number one killer in the developed world. It is important to understand ASCVD given its ubiquity and inevitability. Atherosclerosis can take hold at a very early age, and the role of cholesterol is significant. The causal factors of ASCVD determine prevention strategies. Important metrics and biomarkers found in blood work, as well as diagnostic tests such as coronary artery calcium scores (CAC) and CT angiograms help to determine the level of arterial damage present. Understanding and interpreting calcium scores are key.

title: Early Understanding of Atherosclerosis
content: Atherosclerosis is ubiquitous and inevitable, limiting human longevity. It is important to understand this disease early in life due to its huge impact and the significant tools available for its management. Extending lifespan involves delaying the onset of chronic diseases like atherosclerosis. Risk factors include smoking, hypertension, and high blood and lipid abnormalities. Studies show that ASCVD begins at a young age and early prevention is key.

title: Defining ASCVD and the Role of Cholesterol
content: ASCVD is a disease state characterized by the deposition or the buildup of cholesterol in the artery wall. It begins with a fatty streak that later consolidates into plaques that can ultimately lead to a reduction in blood flow, called ischemia. Ischemia results in tissue damage to the heart and can result in a fatal heart attack. The presence of cholesterol in the artery wall defines atherosclerosis. Cholesterol is an organic molecule, a type of lipid, and is one of the most important molecules in the body. It is used for the cell membrane of every cell in the body and for the synthesis of many hormones.

title: Process of Developing ASCVD
content: The process of developing ASCVD involves the anatomy of blood vessels. The endothelium is a 1-cell layer that lines and protects the arterial lumen, the inside of a blood vessel through which blood flows. The endothelium has complex functions, including modulating vascular tone and playing an important role in modulating inflammatory and thrombotic processes.

title: Artery Structure and Function
content: There is a single layer of endothelial cells lining the entire surface of this artery. Also shown is what’s behind these endothelial cells, the other layers of the artery wall. Unlike veins, arteries have very muscular walls.

title: Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL)
content: LDL, the low density lipoprotein, is a lipid transport particle. LDL is essential for every cell. Cells make cholesterol but not every cell can make enough to meet its own needs. LDL’s zip through the bloodstream.

title: High Density Lipoprotein (HDL)
content: The 2 most people will have heard of is the low density variant (LDL) and the high density variant (HDL). HDL particles will also enter this space from time to time. The difference is the HDLs leave; they don’t get stuck in the subendothelial space.

title: Atherosclerosis Risk Factors
content: One of the risk factors for atherosclerosis is the health of the endothelium. The dominant risk factor is the lipid concentration. Things that are damaging to the endothelium lining blood vessels include uric acid, hyperinsulinemia, elevated glucose levels, and homocysteine.

title: Inflammatory Response to Endothelial Damage
content: The endothelial system reacts in an effort to prevent further damage. The paradox is, the efforts by the endothelium to heal itself is what ultimately kicks off a cascade of events that result in more damage. The endothelium is now dysfunctional and expresses something called selectins and vascular cell adhesion molecules.

title: Role of Monocytes in Atherosclerosis
content: Monocytes, a type of immune cell patrolling in the bloodstream, respond to the damaged endothelium. Monocytes enter the subendothelial space and mature to become macrophages. Macrophages start to ingest the modified / oxidized LDL particles.

title: Formation of Atherosclerotic Plaque
content: When a lot of these foam cells coalesce, it starts to form something called a fatty streak. Chemical signals start to trigger the migration of smooth muscle cells to the area of the injury. This matrix becomes the fibrous cap of the atherosclerotic plaque.

title: Progression of Atherosclerosis
content: It is only now that the lumen of the artery begins to narrow. So much has to happen, years and years before you can start to see damage. And it’s the damage that leads to events. By the time you’re having events, the process covered so far has happened decades earlier.

title: Understanding Plaque Formation and Rupture
content: Plaque can start to become obstructive in arteries, leading to narrowing. Lipid rich plaques can become unstable and rupture, causing serious health issues. The rupture of a plaque leads to the sudden occlusion of blood flow, often causing a heart attack. This process can occur very quickly and without warning, leading to sudden death in some cases.

title: Role of Platelets in Coagulation Cascade
content: When lipids escape from plaque, it activates the coagulation cascade. Platelets, which are present in the blood and whose job is to stop bleeding in case of an injury, serve as a cradle for the coagulation cascade to produce a net of fibrin. This leads to a clot, with red blood cells getting caught in this net, leading to an occlusion of blood flow.

title: Development of Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD)
content: ASCVD can start to develop early in life. The number of particles in the blood is important, as is the health of the endothelium. The disease typically manifests during the 4th-6th decades of life, with a full decade difference between men and women. It is caused by apoB bearing particles (LDL particles) entering the subendothelial space, getting retained, and getting oxidized. This process can start very early in life for some individuals, even in utero.

title: Case Studies of Atherosclerosis
content: Atherosclerosis can be observed in pathology slides, showing the progression of the disease. The disease starts with intimal thickening, an early sign of atherosclerosis. As the disease progresses, lipid cores disrupt the musculoelastic layer above the media layer, leading to more advanced lesions. The disease can progress to a point where the lipid core extends into the media, with parts of the media and the adventitia containing macrophages and lymphocytes, indicating inflammation.

title: Prevalence of Coronary Artery Lesions
content: Coronary artery lesions start to appear after age 11, with the prevalence steadily climbing with age. By age 40, 70% of people have these types of lesions. The incidence of these lesions has likely shifted due to fewer people smoking and better control of lipids.

title: Causal Factors of ASCVD and Prevention Strategies
content: Cholesterol, hypertension, smoking, and metabolic health all play a causal role in ASCVD. Managing lipids is crucial to prevent ASCVD. Typical cholesterol panels include total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides. It is important to get a direct measure of LDL and to measure VLDL cholesterol. The amount of cholesterol within each particle is the same, but the amount of cholesterol within the HDL particle provides little indication of the functionality of the HDL.

title: Understanding LDL and Heart Disease
content: The probability of LDL entering the subendothelial space, getting retained, getting oxidized, etc. is determined by the particle concentration [LDL]. The more particles you have, the more likely it is that particles will go and enter the subendothelial space. People who genetically have low LDL concentration don't get heart disease. It’s not the amount of cholesterol within the LDL that’s a great predictor of the risk. It’s the number of LDL particles (and atherogenic particles in general) that’s a good predictor of risk.

title: Biomarkers of ASCVD
content: The full lipid panel, Lp(a), apoB, and APOE are used to identify biomarkers of ASCVD. These measures tell about the risk but not how much atherosclerosis is currently present. Additional measurements factor into how risk is managed include Homocysteine, Uric acid, Thyroid function, Iron, and Ferritin. Monitoring blood pressure is also important as even slight elevations of blood pressure are significant.

title: Diagnostic Tests for Arterial Damage
content: The 2 most important things we can look at to determine the level of arterial damage present are Coronary artery calcium (CAC) score and A CT angiogram (CTA). Calcium score (CAC) looks at the amount of calcification in the coronary arteries. The CT angiogram (CTA) is a much better test but it comes at a higher cost and it comes with more radiation. A CT scan of the heart captures the calcification.

title: Understanding CAC Scores
content: The CAC score is not something that you follow serially over time. It’s used a couple times to establish risk. There is a clear relationship between the increase in the calcium score (CAC) and the likelihood of a cardiac event. A CAC of 0 is used as the unit case. A CAC of 1-49 is generally considered low and is a 1.2 increase in risk over 8 years. A CAC of 50-99 nearly doubles the risk. A CAC of 100-199 has an odds ratio of up to 3.8. By the time the calcium score is 2,000, the odds ratio is 55.7, significantly higher.

title: Calcium and Heart Disease
content: Calcium starting to show up is a late stage event. You can still be in A, B, C, D, and have a normal calcium score. Only in E is your calcium score abnormal. But a CT angiogram can pick up A, B, C, D. The density of the calcium also matters. The denser the calcium, the lower the risk. Calcification by itself is not a bad thing. It’s actually a good thing; it’s stabilizing the plaque. It’s just that it’s a harbinger of what’s going on.

title: Cholesterol Levels
content: Is there a risk from cholesterol levels being too low? The good news is, no. When you look again at the laboratory report and look at lipid concentrations, you’re looking at what the amount of cholesterol contained within the lipoproteins circulating within the plasma. Consider the biggest reduction in total cholesterol you could have. Let’s say you lowered your total cholesterol from 200 mg/dL to 100 mg/dL. Along the way, you lowered your LDL cholesterol from 130 mg/dL to 40 mg/dL. These are realistic numbers for what that type of dramatic reduction would do. Lipoproteins account for less than 10% of total body cholesterol. Even if you shrink the cholesterol in lipoproteins by 50%, you’re only reducing total body cholesterol by 4.5%. The vast majority of cholesterol still resides in peripheral tissue, and that’s where it’s being turned into hormones.

title: Prevention of ASCVD
content: Overall takeaway: Think about prevention decades in advance. ASCVD is very common. The good news is, this disease takes a really long time to occur. It’s not going to happen overnight. The flip side of that is it takes a while to prevent it as well. It’s a disease that is like moving towards an iceberg at three knots from hundreds of miles away. Just like a slow moving ship towards an iceberg, you can’t wait until you’re looking at the iceberg to do anything about it. Studies look at the effects of drugs (like a statin) over the course of 2 years. The key here is 2 years; this speaks to the nature of this disease. Often you may not see impressive results in this period of time.

title: Understanding apoB
content: The other big takeaway is the importance of understanding apoB and why apoB concentration is such an important metric. It’s not the only metric, but when you want to think about lipids, you want to think about apoB. ApoB captures the risk much better than LDLC, and even non HDLC.

title: Lp(a) Relevance
content: We will have an upcoming podcast on Lp(a) to go deep into that topic. Lp(a) is very relevant for about 10% of the population. Everybody should know their Lp(a) and if it’s elevated, this opens a whole new Pandora’s box of things to think about prevention-wise.

title: Calcium Scores
content: Takeaway related to calcium scores: Calcium scores are really good tests. The CTA is a much better test than the coronary artery calcium (CAC) score; You just have to decide if the additional cost and radiation are worth it. Peter likes the CTA more than the CAC because it’s harder to get fooled. The CAC is a great way to stratify risk, but you’re going to miss a lot of pieces of pathology if they haven’t reached the level of calcification yet.
